{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3440806,"name":"Thomas McDonald","username":"ThomasMcDonald904","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/e8c25b/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-28T18:12:34.709Z","cooked":"

We’ve been trying to set up Pathplanner on our swerve codebase, but it isn’t working well. Indeed, when normally driving we use controller inputs and multiply it by 35 (we know it’s abnormally huge, but it’s what works).

What we do normally:

    def driveRaw(
            self,
            x_speed: float,
            y_speed: float,
            rot_speed: float,
            is_field_relative: bool,
    ):
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("driveX", x_speed)
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("driveY", y_speed)
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("driveRot", rot_speed)
        if is_field_relative:
            base_chassis_speed = ChassisSpeeds.fromFieldRelativeSpeeds(
                x_speed, y_speed, rot_speed, self.getPose().rotation()
            )
        else:
            base_chassis_speed = ChassisSpeeds(x_speed, y_speed, rot_speed)

        corrected_chassis_speed = self.correctForDynamics(base_chassis_speed)

        swerve_module_states = self.swervedrive_kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(
            corrected_chassis_speed
        )

        SwerveDrive4Kinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(
            swerve_module_states, self.swerve_module_fr.max_speed
        )
        SmartDashboard.putNumberArray("moduleSpeeds", [state.speed for state in swerve_module_states])

        self.swerve_module_fl.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[0])
        self.swerve_module_fr.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[1])
        self.swerve_module_bl.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[2])
        self.swerve_module_br.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[3])

However, the code that drives the robot using chassis speeds outputs values around 6 m/s to the swerve modules, even though the max speed in the pathplanner GUI is set to 35.

This is the “from chassis speed” code:

    def driveFromRobotRelativeChassisSpeeds(self, chassis_speeds: ChassisSpeeds) -> None:
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("chassisSpeedsX", chassis_speeds.vx)
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("chassisSpeedsY", chassis_speeds.vy)
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("chassisSpeedsRot", chassis_speeds.omega_dps)

        corrected_chassis_speed = self.correctForDynamics(chassis_speeds)

        swerve_module_states = self.swervedrive_kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(
            corrected_chassis_speed
        )

        SwerveDrive4Kinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(
            swerve_module_states, self.swerve_module_fr.max_speed
        )
        self.swerve_module_fl.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[0])
        self.swerve_module_fr.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[1])
        self.swerve_module_bl.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[2])
        self.swerve_module_br.setDesiredState(swerve_module_states[3])

Does anyone have an idea? Any help is greatly appreciated!

ThomasMcDonald904:

the code that drives the robot using chassis speeds outputs values around 6 m/s to the swerve modules, even though the max speed in the pathplanner GUI is set to 35

Um, I wouldn’t expect an FRC robot to go much faster than 6m/s (about 20fps), and I wouldn’t describe it as “very slow”. 35m/s is about 78mph. What sort of speed were you hoping for?

I wonder if your underlying problem is that you’re not specifying the wheel radius in metres.

Yeah, we know it’s an utterly massive speed . I have reduced the max_speed to 3.0 m/s and it now seems to be working much better. I feel like pathplanner was outputting a number that the swerve programming felt was very small compared to it’s 35 m/s speed. Now I’m having the problem that NamedCommands aren’t being called in a ParallelCommand group for example.

When the speeds are off by a constant factor like yours are, that tells me there could be an issue with the unit conversion. I’d recommend checking your constants and encoder conversion factors to make sure they line up with the native units of your motor.
